canonical_explanation.text: The number system in Class 9 covers real numbers, which include both rational and irrational numbers. A rational number can be expressed as p/q where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0. An irrational number cannot be expressed as p/q; examples include √2, √3, and π. Every real number has a unique point on the number line. Decimal expansions help distinguish rationals (terminating or non-terminating recurring) from irrationals (non-terminating non-recurring). Laws of exponents extend to all real numbers, and rationalisation is used to simplify expressions with surds in the denominator.
rules: Rational numbers have terminating or non-terminating recurring decimal expansions
Irrational numbers have non-terminating non-recurring decimal expansions
Every real number corresponds to a unique point on the number line
Laws of exponents: a^m × a^n = a^(m+n), (a^m)^n = a^(mn), a^m/a^n = a^(m-n), (ab)^n = a^n × b^n
To rationalise 1/(a+√b), multiply numerator and denominator by (a−√b)

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an irrational number?
questions.explanation_correct: √2 = 1.41421356... is a non-terminating non-recurring decimal, so it is irrational. √9 = 3 (rational), 3/4 and 0.75 are also rational.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3/4 = 0.75 is rational, √9 = 3 is rational. Only √2 cannot be expressed as p/q, making it irrational.

questions.question_text: Every rational number is:
questions.explanation_correct: Every rational number is a real number because the set of real numbers includes all rational and irrational numbers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not every rational number is a natural number (e.g., −1/2), whole number, or integer (e.g., 3/4). But every rational number is a real number.

questions.question_text: The number 0 is a rational number.
questions.explanation_correct: 0 can be expressed as 0/1, which is of the form p/q where q ≠ 0. Therefore 0 is a rational number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 0 is rational because it can be written as 0/1 (p/q form with q ≠ 0).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a rational number?
questions.explanation_correct: √16 = 4, which is an integer and hence a rational number. √5, √3, and π are all irrational.
questions.explanation_incorrect: √5, √3, and π are irrational. √16 = 4 = 4/1, which is rational.

questions.question_text: Between any two rational numbers, there exist:

options.text: A finite number of rational numbers

questions.explanation_correct: Between any two rational numbers, there are infinitely many rational numbers. This is called the density property of rational numbers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are not zero, one, or a finite number. The density property guarantees infinitely many rational numbers between any two rational numbers.

questions.question_text: A number that cannot be expressed in the form p/q, where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0, is called a(n) ___ number.
questions.explanation_correct: By definition, a number that cannot be written as p/q (with p, q integers and q ≠ 0) is an irrational number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If a number cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers, it is not rational. Such numbers are called irrational numbers.

questions.question_text: Which set of numbers includes all the others?
questions.explanation_correct: Real numbers include all natural numbers, whole numbers, integers, rational numbers, and irrational numbers. It is the most inclusive set listed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Natural numbers ⊂ Whole numbers ⊂ Integers ⊂ Rational numbers ⊂ Real numbers. So real numbers include all others.

questions.question_text: √7 is a rational number.
questions.explanation_correct: 7 is not a perfect square, so √7 is an irrational number. Its decimal expansion is non-terminating and non-recurring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: √7 = 2.6457513... which is non-terminating and non-recurring. Therefore it is irrational, not rational.

questions.question_text: On the number line, √2 lies between which two integers?
questions.explanation_correct: Since 1² = 1 and 2² = 4, we have 1 < 2 < 4, so 1 < √2 < 2. Thus √2 lies between 1 and 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: √2 ≈ 1.414, which is between 1 and 2. It does not lie between 0 and 1 or between 2 and 3.

questions.question_text: To represent √5 on the number line using Pythagoras' theorem, we can construct a right triangle with legs of length:
questions.explanation_correct: 1² + 2² = 1 + 4 = 5, so the hypotenuse is √5. Since √4 = 2, options A, B, and C all give legs whose squares sum to 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All three options produce a right triangle with hypotenuse √5 because 1² + 2² = 5 in each case.

questions.question_text: √3 lies between ___ and ___ on the number line.
questions.explanation_correct: Since 1² = 1 < 3 < 4 = 2², we get 1 < √3 < 2. So √3 lies between 1 and 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We need integers n such that n² < 3 < (n+1)². Since 1 < 3 < 4, √3 lies between 1 and 2.

questions.question_text: The decimal expansion of 1/3 is:
questions.explanation_correct: 1/3 = 0.3333... where the digit 3 repeats indefinitely. This is a non-terminating recurring decimal, which is characteristic of rational numbers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1/3 does not terminate at 0.3 or 0.33. The digit 3 repeats forever, making it non-terminating but recurring (not non-recurring).

questions.question_text: Which type of decimal expansion represents an irrational number?
questions.explanation_correct: Irrational numbers have non-terminating non-recurring decimal expansions. Terminating and non-terminating recurring decimals represent rational numbers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Terminating and recurring decimals are rational. Only non-terminating non-recurring decimals represent irrational numbers.

questions.question_text: The decimal expansion of 7/8 is terminating.
questions.explanation_correct: 7/8 = 0.875, which terminates. A rational number p/q in lowest terms has a terminating decimal if and only if the prime factorisation of q contains only 2s and 5s. Here q = 8 = 2³.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 7/8 = 0.875 exactly. Since 8 = 2³ has no prime factors other than 2 and 5, the decimal terminates.

questions.question_text: Simplify: 2³ × 2⁵
questions.explanation_correct: Using the law a^m × a^n = a^(m+n): 2³ × 2⁵ = 2^(3+5) = 2⁸.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When multiplying powers with the same base, add the exponents (not multiply). So 2³ × 2⁵ = 2⁸, not 2¹⁵.

questions.question_text: What is the value of (3²)³?
questions.explanation_correct: Using (a^m)^n = a^(mn): (3²)³ = 3^(2×3) = 3⁶. Also, 3² = 9, so (3²)³ = 9³. Both B and C are correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: (3²)³ uses the power-of-a-power rule: multiply exponents. 2 × 3 = 6, so (3²)³ = 3⁶ = 9³ = 729.
When dividing powers with the same base, subtract exponents: 7 − 4 = 3, so the answer is 5³.

questions.question_text: Rationalise the denominator of 1/√5:
questions.explanation_correct: Multiply numerator and denominator by √5: 1/√5 × √5/√5 = √5/5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To rationalise, multiply top and bottom by √5. This gives √5/(√5 × √5) = √5/5.

questions.question_text: Rationalise the denominator of 1/√3:
questions.explanation_correct: Multiply numerator and denominator by √3: 1/√3 = √3/(√3 × √3) = √3/3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rationalisation means removing the surd from the denominator. 1/√3 × √3/√3 = √3/3.

questions.question_text: To rationalise 1/(2+√3), we multiply numerator and denominator by (2−√3).
questions.explanation_correct: Multiplying by the conjugate (2−√3) gives denominator (2+√3)(2−√3) = 4−3 = 1, which is rational.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The conjugate of (2+√3) is (2−√3). Multiplying by the conjugate is the standard rationalisation technique.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is irrational?
questions.explanation_correct: √(4/9) = 2/3 (rational). 0.121212... is recurring (rational). −7/11 is rational. √(2/3) is irrational since neither 2 nor 3 is a perfect square.
questions.explanation_incorrect: √(2/3) cannot be simplified to a ratio of integers. The other options are all rational numbers.

questions.question_text: If x = 3 + 2√2, what is the value of x + 1/x?
The product of a non-zero rational number and an irrational number is always:
questions.explanation_correct: The product of a non-zero rational number and an irrational number is always irrational. For example, 2 × √3 = 2√3, which is irrational.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the rational number is non-zero, the product with an irrational number cannot be rational. It is always irrational.

questions.question_text: To locate √3 on the number line, we first construct a right triangle with base and perpendicular of lengths:
questions.explanation_correct: Using a right triangle with legs √2 and 1: hypotenuse = √(2+1) = √3. We first locate √2, then use it to construct √3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1² + 1² = 2, giving √2, not √3. We need (√2)² + 1² = 2+1 = 3, giving hypotenuse √3.

questions.question_text: Using successive magnification, √2 correct to one decimal place is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: √2 = 1.41421356... Correct to one decimal place, this rounds to 1.4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: √2 ≈ 1.41421... The digit after the first decimal place is 1 (less than 5), so we round down to 1.4.

questions.question_text: The decimal expansion of 1/7 is 0.142857142857... This shows that 1/7 is:
questions.explanation_correct: The block 142857 repeats endlessly, making it a non-terminating recurring decimal. This confirms 1/7 is a rational number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The repeating pattern 142857 shows the decimal is recurring. Non-terminating recurring decimals are always rational.

questions.question_text: Which of the following has a terminating decimal expansion?
questions.explanation_correct: 80 = 2⁴ × 5. Since the denominator has only factors of 2 and 5, 7/80 = 0.0875 (terminating). The others have denominators with factors other than 2 and 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A fraction in lowest terms has a terminating decimal if and only if the denominator has no prime factors other than 2 and 5. Only 80 = 2⁴ × 5 satisfies this.

questions.question_text: The decimal expansion of 3/11 is non-terminating recurring.
questions.explanation_correct: 3/11 = 0.272727... The block 27 repeats. Since 11 has a prime factor other than 2 and 5, the decimal is non-terminating recurring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 11 is not of the form 2^m × 5^n, so 3/11 must have a non-terminating recurring decimal expansion.

questions.question_text: Simplify: (2⁵ × 2⁷) / 2⁹
questions.explanation_incorrect: First add exponents in the numerator: 5+7 = 12. Then subtract the denominator exponent: 12−9 = 3. Answer is 2³.

questions.question_text: What is the value of 64^(1/3)?
questions.explanation_incorrect: 64^(1/3) means the cube root of 64. Since 4 × 4 × 4 = 64, the answer is 4.

questions.question_text: The value of 125^(2/3) is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: 125^(2/3) = (125^(1/3))² = 5² = 25. The cube root of 125 is 5, and 5 squared is 25.
questions.explanation_incorrect: First find the cube root of 125: ∛125 = 5. Then square it: 5² = 25.

questions.question_text: Rationalise the denominator of 1/(√5 − √3):
questions.explanation_correct: Multiply by (√5+√3)/(√5+√3): numerator = √5+√3, denominator = 5−3 = 2. Result: (√5+√3)/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Use the conjugate (√5+√3). The denominator becomes (√5)²−(√3)² = 5−3 = 2. So the answer is (√5+√3)/2.

questions.question_text: The rationalised form of 6/(√7 + √5) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Multiply by (√7−√5)/(√7−√5): 6(√7−√5)/(7−5) = 6(√7−√5)/2 = 3(√7−√5). Both B and C represent the same value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using conjugate: 6(√7−√5)/(7−5) = 6(√7−√5)/2 = 3(√7−√5). Options B and C are equivalent.

questions.question_text: After rationalising, 1/(√2 + 1) equals ___ − ___.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conjugate of (√2+1) is (√2−1). Denominator becomes 2−1 = 1. So the answer is √2−1.

questions.question_text: The sum of a rational number and an irrational number is:
questions.explanation_correct: The sum of a rational number and an irrational number is always irrational. For example, 2 + √3 is irrational.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the sum were rational, then subtracting the rational part would make the irrational part rational, which is a contradiction.

questions.question_text: √10 lies between 3 and 4 on the number line.
questions.explanation_correct: Since 3² = 9 < 10 < 16 = 4², we have 3 < √10 < 4. So √10 lies between 3 and 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Check: 3² = 9 and 4² = 16. Since 9 < 10 < 16, it follows that 3 < √10 < 4.

questions.question_text: Express 0.9999... (recurring) as a fraction:
questions.explanation_correct: Let x = 0.999... Then 10x = 9.999..., so 10x − x = 9, giving 9x = 9, hence x = 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using algebra: if x = 0.999..., then 10x = 9.999..., so 9x = 9, giving x = 1. This is a well-known result.

questions.question_text: Simplify: (3^(1/2))⁴
Classify each of the following as rational or irrational: (i) 2−√5 (ii) (3+√23)−√23 (iii) 1/(√2)
questions.explanation_correct: (i) 2−√5 is irrational (rational − irrational). (ii) (3+√23)−√23 = 3, which is rational. (iii) 1/√2 = √2/2, which is irrational.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Check each: 2−√5 has an irrational part, so it is irrational. The √23 terms cancel in (ii), leaving 3. 1/√2 is irrational.

questions.question_text: Express 0.4̄7̄ (i.e., 0.474747...) as a fraction in simplest form:
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a two-digit recurring block, multiply by 100. Then 100x − x = 47, so x = 47/99.

questions.explanation_correct: Using a² − b² = (a+b)(a−b) where a = √5+√2 and b = √5−√2: (a+b) = 2√5, (a−b) = 2√2. Product = 2√5 × 2√2 = 4√10.

questions.question_text: If a = 5 + 2√6 and b = 1/a, what is a² + b²?
questions.explanation_incorrect: First rationalise b = 5−2√6. Then use (a+b)² = a²+2ab+b², giving a²+b² = (a+b)²−2ab = 100−2 = 98.

questions.question_text: Find three irrational numbers between √2 and √3:
questions.explanation_correct: Since √2 ≈ 1.414 and √3 ≈ 1.732, we need irrationals between them. √2.1, √2.5, √2.9 are all irrational and lie between √2 and √3 (since 2 < 2.1, 2.5, 2.9 < 3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options B (rationals), C (√4=2 > √3), and D (integers/rationals outside range) are incorrect. √2.1, √2.5, √2.9 all lie between √2 and √3.

questions.question_text: Without actual division, which of the following will have a terminating decimal expansion?
questions.explanation_correct: 125 = 5³ (only factor is 5). A fraction terminates if the denominator (in lowest terms) has only 2 and 5 as prime factors. 24 = 2³×3, 12 = 2²×3, 30 = 2×3×5 all have factor 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Check denominators: 125 = 5³ (only 5s), 24 = 2³×3, 12 = 2²×3, 30 = 2×3×5. Only 125 has factors of only 2 and 5.

questions.question_text: Visualise the representation of 4.2̄6̄ (i.e., 4.262626...) on the number line up to 4 decimal places. This number lies between:
questions.explanation_correct: 4.2626... lies between 4 and 5, also between 4.2 and 4.3, and more precisely between 4.26 and 4.27 using successive magnification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: By successive magnification: 4.2626... is between 4 and 5 → between 4.2 and 4.3 → between 4.26 and 4.27. All are correct.
Add exponents in numerator: 1/2 + 1/4 = 3/4. Subtract denominator exponent: 3/4 − 1/2 = 1/4.

questions.question_text: Rationalise: 1/(√7 − 2)
questions.explanation_correct: Multiply by (√7+2)/(√7+2): numerator = √7+2, denominator = 7−4 = 3. Answer: (√7+2)/3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conjugate of (√7−2) is (√7+2). Denominator = (√7)²−2² = 7−4 = 3. So result = (√7+2)/3.

questions.question_text: Express 0.001̄ (0.001001001... recurring) as a fraction in simplest form: ___
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a three-digit recurring block starting right after the decimal, multiply by 1000. Then 1000x − x = 1, so x = 1/999.

questions.question_text: If 2^(x+3) = 4^(x−1), find the value of x:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Express both sides with base 2: 2^(x+3) = 2^(2x−2). Equating exponents: x+3 = 2x−2, so x = 5.
